fields.name: Labrador Retriever
fields.overview: Labrador Retrievers are friendly, outgoing, and active dogs. They are America's most popular breed and make excellent family companions.
fields.breed_history: Originated in Newfoundland, Canada in the 1500s, where they helped fishermen haul nets and catch fish. Brought to England in the 1800s and refined into the breed we know today. Recognized by AKC in 1917.
fields.original_purpose: Retrieving fishing nets and fish for fishermen
fields.fun_fact_1: Labradors have been America's #1 most popular dog breed for over 30 consecutive years!
fields.fun_fact_2: They have a water-resistant coat and an 'otter tail' that acts like a rudder when swimming.
fields.fun_fact_3: Labs come in three colors: yellow, black, and chocolate - all can appear in the same litter!
fields.fun_fact_4: Their soft mouth allows them to retrieve game without damaging it.
fields.fun_fact_5: Labs are the most popular choice for guide dogs, search-and-rescue, and therapy work.
fields.fun_fact_6: They were originally called St. John's Dogs or Lesser Newfoundland Dogs.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed food, 2.5-3 cups daily in 2 meals. Protein 20-25%, moderate fat. Include joint supplements as they age. Monitor calories carefully - Labs love food!
fields.feeding_notes: Extremely food-motivated and prone to obesity. Use measuring cups and avoid table scraps. Feed at scheduled times. Slow-feeder bowls can help prevent gulping. Risk of bloat - no exercise after meals.
fields.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, obesity, ear infections, exercise-induced collapse, progressive retinal atrophy, heart disease
fields.health_screening: OFA hip and elbow evaluations, eye exam, EIC genetic test, cardiac screening, annual wellness exams
fields.genetic_conditions: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Exercise-Induced Collapse (EIC), Centronuclear Myopathy
fields.grooming_details: Brush weekly, daily during seasonal shedding. Bathe every 6-8 weeks. Trim nails monthly. Clean ears weekly (prone to infections). Check between toes regularly.
fields.exercise_details: Requires 60-90 minutes daily exercise. Love swimming, fetch, hiking, and running. High-energy dogs that need both physical and mental activity. Puppies need controlled exercise to protect developing joints.
fields.mental_stimulation: Retrieving games, obedience training, scent work, puzzle feeders, swimming activities. Need variety to prevent boredom.
fields.training_tips: Highly trainable with positive reinforcement. Food motivation makes training easy. Start early - they remain puppy-like for 2-3 years. Consistency important. Can be exuberant and needs impulse control training.
fields.socialization_needs: Generally friendly but early socialization important. Expose to people, dogs, and environments. Puppy classes recommended. Their friendliness should be channeled appropriately.
fields.temperament_description: Friendly, outgoing, and active with even temperament. Gentle, intelligent, and eager to please. Not typically aggressive or territorial. Love everyone - poor guard dogs!
fields.behavior_traits: Food obsessed, mouthy when young, love water, may jump on people, chew when bored, slow to mature, retrieve instinct, social with dogs and people
fields.ideal_home: House with yard preferred but adaptable. Need active families. Great with children. Can adapt to various living situations if exercised adequately.
fields.climate_tolerance: Good cold tolerance, moderate heat tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Prone to obesity - strict diet management essential. May develop separation anxiety. Can be destructive if bored or under-exercised. Needs regular ear cleaning to prevent infections.

fields.name: German Shepherd
fields.overview: German Shepherds are confident, courageous, and intelligent working dogs. They are loyal protectors and versatile companions.
fields.breed_history: Developed in Germany in the late 1800s by Captain Max von Stephanitz, who aimed to create the perfect herding dog. Standardized in 1899, they quickly became valued for police and military work worldwide.
fields.fun_fact_1: German Shepherds were the first guide dogs for the blind, establishing the concept of service dogs.
fields.fun_fact_2: They rank 3rd in intelligence among all dog breeds, excelling at learning complex commands.
fields.fun_fact_3: Famous German Shepherds include Rin Tin Tin and Strongheart, both Hollywood stars in the 1920s.
fields.fun_fact_4: They are the second most popular breed in the United States.
fields.fun_fact_5: Their nose has approximately 225 million scent receptors, making them excellent detection dogs.
fields.fun_fact_6: German Shepherds can be trained to perform over 50 different tasks for police, military, and service work.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed formula with glucosamine for joint health. Feed 3-4 cups daily divided into 2 meals. Protein content should be 18-22%. Include omega fatty acids for coat and skin health.
fields.feeding_notes: Risk of bloat (gastric dilatation-volvulus) - feed smaller meals and avoid exercise after eating. Some individuals have sensitive stomachs. Maintain lean body condition to reduce stress on joints.
fields.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, degenerative myelopathy, bloat, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, perianal fistulas, allergies, hemangiosarcoma
fields.health_screening: OFA hip and elbow certification, cardiac exam, DM genetic testing, annual vet checkups, joint assessments for older dogs
fields.genetic_conditions: Degenerative Myelopathy (DM), Hip Dysplasia, Elbow Dysplasia, Von Willebrand's Disease
fields.grooming_details: Brush 3-4 times weekly, daily during shedding seasons. Bathe every 8-12 weeks. Trim nails every 3-4 weeks. Check and clean ears weekly. Dental care important.
fields.exercise_details: Needs 60-120 minutes of daily vigorous exercise. Include walks, runs, training sessions, and play. Excellent for agility, tracking, and protection sports. Mental stimulation equally important.
fields.mental_stimulation: Advanced obedience, protection training, nose work, puzzle toys, job or purpose (even if simple tasks). They need to work and use their minds.
fields.training_tips: Extremely trainable but requires confident, consistent leadership. Start early with socialization and obedience. Use firm but fair positive reinforcement. They excel in structured training environments.
fields.socialization_needs: Critical early socialization to prevent overprotectiveness. Expose to various people, animals, sounds, and situations. Their natural guarding instinct needs proper channeling.
fields.temperament_description: Confident, courageous, intelligent, loyal, and protective. Can be aloof with strangers but not aggressive without cause. Strong work ethic and desire to serve their family.
fields.behavior_traits: Natural guarding instinct, may be territorial, forms strong bonds with family, can be vocal, high prey drive, needs a job or purpose, may herd children or other pets
fields.ideal_home: House with secure yard required. Not suitable for apartments unless extensively exercised. Best with experienced owners who understand working breeds and can provide structure.
fields.climate_tolerance: Excellent cold tolerance, moderate heat tolerance (requires shade and water)
fields.special_considerations: Needs experienced owner who can establish leadership. Can develop behavioral issues if under-stimulated. Strong prey drive may pose challenges with small pets. Regular veterinary care important for joint health.

fields.name: Golden Retriever
fields.overview: Golden Retrievers are friendly, intelligent, and devoted dogs. They are great family pets and excel in obedience training.
fields.breed_history: Developed in the Scottish Highlands during the 1800s by Lord Tweedmouth, who crossbred the Yellow Retriever with the now-extinct Tweed Water Spaniel. The breed was officially recognized by the Kennel Club in 1911.
fields.fun_fact_1: Golden Retrievers have a strong instinct to carry things in their mouths and can carry eggs without breaking them!
fields.fun_fact_2: They rank 4th in Stanley Coren's intelligence rankings, making them one of the smartest dog breeds.
fields.fun_fact_3: Their water-repellent coat and webbed feet make them excellent swimmers.
fields.fun_fact_4: The breed became one of America's most popular dogs since the 1970s.
fields.fun_fact_5: Golden Retrievers are commonly used as service dogs, therapy dogs, and search-and-rescue dogs.
fields.fun_fact_6: They were bred to work with hunters, so they have a natural eagerness to please their owners.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality dry dog food formulated for large, active breeds. Feed 2-3 cups daily divided into two meals. Look for foods rich in protein (chicken, fish, lamb) and omega-3 fatty acids for coat health. Avoid overfeeding as they are prone to obesity.
fields.feeding_notes: Prone to bloat - avoid exercise immediately after meals. Monitor weight carefully as they love to eat. Fresh water should always be available. Treats should not exceed 10% of daily calories.
fields.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, elbow dysplasia, eye conditions (cataracts, progressive retinal atrophy), heart problems (subvalvular aortic stenosis), cancer (especially hemangiosarcoma and lymphoma), skin allergies, ear infections
fields.health_screening: OFA hip and elbow evaluations, cardiac exam, ophthalmologist evaluation, genetic testing for PRA and ichthyosis. Annual wellness exams recommended.
fields.genetic_conditions: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Muscular Dystrophy, von Willebrand's Disease, Ichthyosis
fields.grooming_details: Brush 2-3 times per week, daily during shedding season. Bathe every 6-8 weeks. Trim nails monthly. Clean ears weekly to prevent infections. Check and clean between paw pads regularly.
fields.exercise_details: Requires 60-90 minutes of daily exercise. Activities should include walks, runs, swimming, fetch, and playtime. Excellent jogging or hiking companions. Needs both physical and mental exercise.
fields.mental_stimulation: Puzzle toys, obedience training, retrieving games, scent work, agility courses. They excel at learning new commands and tricks.
fields.training_tips: Highly trainable and eager to please. Use positive reinforcement methods. Start socialization and basic training early. They respond well to consistency and patience. Avoid harsh corrections as they are sensitive.
fields.socialization_needs: Early and ongoing socialization with people, dogs, and various environments. Naturally friendly but need exposure to prevent shyness. Puppy classes highly recommended.
fields.temperament_description: Friendly, reliable, trustworthy, kind, confident, and not aggressive. They are gentle, patient, and eager to please. Known for their stable temperament and love of people.
fields.behavior_traits: Mouthy behavior (loves to carry things), high food motivation, water-loving, gentle with children, social with other dogs, minimal guarding instinct, may jump on people when excited
fields.ideal_home: House with a fenced yard preferred. Can adapt to apartment living if given adequate exercise. Best with active families who can provide attention and activity.
fields.climate_tolerance: Tolerates cold weather well, moderate tolerance for heat (needs shade and water in summer)
fields.special_considerations: Prone to separation anxiety - should not be left alone for long periods. Needs family interaction. Sheds heavily twice a year. May develop destructive behaviors if under-exercised or bored.

fields.name: Pomeranian
fields.overview: Pomeranians are tiny, lively dogs with a bold personality and fluffy double coat. Despite their small size, they have big personalities.
fields.breed_history: Descended from large Spitz-type sled dogs, Pomeranians were bred down in size in the Pomerania region. Queen Victoria owned a small Pomeranian, which popularized the smaller variety in the late 1800s.
fields.original_purpose: Companion dog (bred down from larger working Spitz dogs)
fields.fun_fact_1: Two Pomeranians survived the Titanic disaster in 1912, traveling in first class with their owners.
fields.fun_fact_2: Queen Victoria, Mozart, and Marie Antoinette all owned Pomeranians.
fields.fun_fact_3: Pomeranians typically weigh only 3-7 lbs but think they're much larger dogs!
fields.fun_fact_4: They come in 23 different color combinations, more than any other breed.
fields.fun_fact_5: Pomeranians have a 'pom prance' - a distinctive bouncy walk that shows their confidence.
fields.fun_fact_6: Despite their tiny size, they make excellent alert watchdogs with their loud bark.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality small breed dog food, 1/4 to 1/2 cup daily divided into 2-3 small meals. Choose foods with high-quality protein and appropriate calorie density for their metabolism. Avoid overfeeding.
fields.feeding_notes: Small frequent meals prevent hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), especially in puppies. Dental-friendly kibble size important. Prone to obesity - measure portions carefully. Fresh water always available.
fields.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, tracheal collapse, dental problems, hypoglycemia, alopecia X (black skin disease), eye problems, heart issues
fields.health_screening: Patellar evaluation, cardiac exam, ophthalmologist evaluation, dental checkups every 6 months. Regular vet visits essential.
fields.genetic_conditions: Patellar Luxation, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Collapsing Trachea
fields.grooming_details: Brush 2-3 times weekly minimum, daily during shedding season. Professional grooming every 4-6 weeks recommended. Trim around paws, ears, and rear. Special attention to undercoat.
fields.coat_type: Double coat with harsh-textured outer coat and soft, dense undercoat
fields.exercise_details: Short walks 20-30 minutes daily. Indoor play sessions adequate. Avoid overexertion in extreme temperatures. Mental stimulation as important as physical exercise.
fields.mental_stimulation: Trick training, puzzle toys, hide and seek, interactive games. Pomeranians are intelligent and love learning new things.
fields.training_tips: Start early with positive reinforcement. Can be stubborn - patience and consistency key. Housetraining can be challenging. Crate training recommended. Socialize early to prevent excessive barking and small dog syndrome.
fields.socialization_needs: Critical early socialization to prevent fearfulness and aggression. Expose to various people, dogs (appropriate sizes), sounds, and environments. Puppy classes highly beneficial.
fields.temperament_description: Confident, bold, lively, and alert. Despite small size, has a big personality. Affectionate with family, can be territorial. Intelligent and curious with fox-like expression.
fields.behavior_traits: Alert watchdog, barks at strangers, can be possessive of owners, bold and fearless attitude, may challenge larger dogs, loves being center of attention, loyal to family
fields.ideal_home: Apartment or house suitable. Best with adults or older children due to fragile size. Good for seniors. Needs supervision outdoors due to small size and prey animal vulnerability.
fields.climate_tolerance: Sensitive to extreme heat and cold. Needs coat in winter, shade and AC in summer. Not an outdoor dog.
fields.special_considerations: Fragile - not suitable for homes with young children. Prone to dental disease requiring regular care. Trachea sensitive to collars - use harness. Can develop small dog syndrome if not properly trained. Escape artist - secure fencing essential.

fields.name: Beagle
fields.overview: Beagles are merry, friendly scent hounds known for their excellent sense of smell and tracking ability. They are gentle, even-tempered, and great with families.
fields.breed_history: Beagles have existed for centuries in England, used for hunting rabbits and hare. The modern breed was developed in the 1830s. The name possibly comes from the French 'begueule' meaning 'open throat' referring to their bay.
fields.original_purpose: Scent hound for hunting small game, particularly rabbits
fields.fun_fact_1: Beagles have approximately 220 million scent receptors, making them exceptional tracking dogs.
fields.fun_fact_2: Snoopy from the Peanuts comic strip is the world's most famous Beagle!
fields.fun_fact_3: Beagles have three distinct vocalizations: a bark, a bay (howl), and a growl.
fields.fun_fact_4: President Lyndon B. Johnson had several Beagles in the White House named Him, Her, and Edgar.
fields.fun_fact_5: Beagles are used in airports worldwide as detection dogs for contraband food and agricultural products.
fields.fun_fact_6: Their white-tipped tail was bred specifically so hunters could see them in tall grass.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality medium breed food, 1.5-2 cups daily divided into 2 meals. Moderate protein (20-25%) and fat. Monitor closely as Beagles are prone to obesity. Avoid free-feeding.
fields.feeding_notes: Beagles are extremely food-motivated and will overeat. Measure portions carefully. Prone to eating anything - keep human food out of reach. Use puzzle feeders to slow eating. Regular weight monitoring essential.
fields.common_health_issues: Obesity, hip dysplasia, cherry eye, epilepsy, hypothyroidism, ear infections, intervertebral disc disease, beagle dwarfism
fields.health_screening: Hip evaluation, thyroid testing, eye examination, cardiac screening. Regular ear checks. Annual wellness exams important.
fields.genetic_conditions: Musladin-Lueke Syndrome (MLS), Factor VII Deficiency, Neonatal Cerebellar Cortical Degeneration
fields.grooming_details: Brush weekly with medium-bristle brush. Bathe monthly or when smelly. Clean ears weekly (floppy ears prone to infection). Trim nails every 2-3 weeks. Check and clean between paw pads.
fields.exercise_details: Needs 60+ minutes daily exercise. Long walks, sniffing time essential. Excellent for hiking. Strong tracking instinct - must be on leash or in secure area. Loves following scent trails.
fields.mental_stimulation: Scent work and tracking games, puzzle feeders, hide-and-seek with treats, nose work classes. Their nose needs as much exercise as their body!
fields.training_tips: Food motivation helps training. Can be stubborn - patience essential. Easily distracted by scents. Short, fun training sessions work best. Recall training challenging due to scent-driven nature. Positive reinforcement only.
fields.socialization_needs: Generally friendly and social. Early exposure to people, dogs, and environments beneficial. Pack animals - enjoy company of other dogs. Puppy classes recommended.
fields.temperament_description: Merry, friendly, curious, and determined. Even-tempered and gentle. Not aggressive but can be vocal. Love companionship - don't like being alone. Happy-go-lucky attitude.
fields.behavior_traits: Follows nose constantly, food-obsessed, vocal (barks, bays, howls), escape artists, pack mentality, may wander if catches scent, friendly with everyone, not protective
fields.ideal_home: House with securely fenced yard essential. Not suitable for apartments due to vocality. Good with families and other pets. Needs company - not good alone for long periods.
fields.climate_tolerance: Good tolerance to both cold and heat, though not extreme temperatures
fields.special_considerations: Escape artists - needs secure 6ft fencing. Will follow nose into dangerous situations. Prone to obesity - strict diet essential. Can bay loudly - may disturb neighbors. Should not be off-leash in unsecured areas.

fields.name: Bulldog
fields.overview: Bulldogs are calm, courageous, and affectionate dogs with a distinctive wrinkled face and pushed-in nose. They are gentle, loyal companions despite their tough appearance.
fields.breed_history: Originally bred in England for bull-baiting in the 13th century. After this sport was banned in 1835, breeders developed the gentler, smaller companion dog we know today. Recognized by AKC in 1886.
fields.fun_fact_1: The Bulldog is the official mascot of over 40 universities, including Yale, Georgetown, and the University of Georgia.
fields.fun_fact_2: Winston Churchill was often compared to a Bulldog due to his jowly face and tenacious spirit.
fields.fun_fact_3: Bulldogs can't swim well due to their heavy front and flat face - they need life jackets near water!
fields.fun_fact_4: Most Bulldogs are born via C-section due to their large heads and narrow hips.
fields.fun_fact_5: They snore, snort, and wheeze loudly due to their short snouts - it's completely normal!
fields.fun_fact_6: Despite their tough appearance, Bulldogs are known as one of the gentlest breeds.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality medium breed food, 2-3 cups daily divided into 2 meals. Moderate protein, lower fat to prevent obesity. Consider food for sensitive stomachs. Avoid corn and wheat if allergies present.
fields.feeding_notes: Prone to obesity and bloat. Use slow-feeder bowls. Avoid exercise immediately after meals. Many have food allergies - may need limited ingredient diet. Monitor weight carefully - extra weight stresses breathing.
fields.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic syndrome, hip dysplasia, cherry eye, skin fold dermatitis, respiratory problems, heat intolerance, heart disease, allergies
fields.health_screening: Cardiac evaluation, hip evaluation, tracheal evaluation, eye examination. Regular skin fold cleaning. Breathing assessment crucial.
fields.genetic_conditions: Brachycephalic Obstructive Airway Syndrome (BOAS), Hyperuricosuria, Hereditary Cataracts
fields.grooming_details: Brush 2-3 times weekly. Clean facial wrinkles DAILY with damp cloth and dry thoroughly to prevent infection. Bathe every 4-6 weeks. Trim nails every 2-3 weeks. Clean tail pocket if present.
fields.exercise_details: Short walks 20-30 minutes daily, split into multiple sessions. Avoid exercise in heat or humidity. Indoor play appropriate. Do NOT over-exercise - monitor for breathing difficulty. Swimming dangerous without life jacket.
fields.mental_stimulation: Gentle puzzle toys, short training sessions, indoor games. Not high energy but enjoy mental engagement. Keep activities low-key.
fields.training_tips: Can be stubborn. Use patience, consistency, and positive reinforcement. Food motivation helps. Short training sessions due to breathing limitations. Socialization important. Housetraining can be challenging.
fields.socialization_needs: Generally friendly but early socialization helps. Expose to various people, dogs, and environments. Usually good with others but proper introduction important.
fields.temperament_description: Calm, courageous, friendly, and dignified. Affectionate and loyal to family. Gentle and patient, especially with children. Can be stubborn but not aggressive. Low energy but playful in spurts.
fields.behavior_traits: Stubborn streak, loves being with people, can be lazy, snores loudly, drools, sensitive to tone of voice, may be possessive of food, gentle with children
fields.ideal_home: Apartment or house suitable - low exercise needs. Air-conditioned environment essential. Best indoors. Good for all family types. Not suitable for hot climates or very active owners.
fields.climate_tolerance: Excellent cold tolerance, VERY poor heat tolerance - can be life-threatening
fields.special_considerations: Serious breathing issues - cannot tolerate heat, humidity, or over-exercise. High vet costs common. Requires daily wrinkle cleaning. Cannot fly on many airlines due to breathing risks. Drools and passes gas frequently. May require expensive surgeries for breathing problems.

fields.name: Pug
fields.overview: Pugs are charming, mischievous, and loving dogs with distinctive wrinkled faces and curled tails. They are playful companions with huge personalities in small bodies.
fields.breed_history: Bred by Chinese emperors over 2,000 years ago as cherished companions. Brought to Europe in the 16th century by Dutch traders. Became popular with European royalty, especially in Holland and England.
fields.fun_fact_1: The Latin phrase 'multum in parvo' (much in little) perfectly describes the Pug's big personality!
fields.fun_fact_2: A group of pugs is called a 'grumble' due to the snorting sounds they make.
fields.fun_fact_3: Pugs were the official dog of the House of Orange in Holland after one saved a prince's life.
fields.fun_fact_4: Their wrinkles were intentionally bred to resemble Chinese characters.
fields.fun_fact_5: Josephine, wife of Napoleon Bonaparte, had a Pug named Fortune who bit Napoleon on their wedding night!
fields.fun_fact_6: Pugs are one of the oldest dog breeds, dating back to 400 BC.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality small breed food, 1-1.5 cups daily divided into 2 meals. Moderate protein and fat. Choose kibble appropriate for flat-faced breeds. Avoid overfeeding as very prone to obesity.
fields.feeding_notes: Extremely food-motivated and prone to obesity. Measure portions carefully. Slow feeders help. Many have food sensitivities. Monitor weight closely - obesity worsens breathing. Fresh water always available.
fields.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic syndrome, eye problems (corneal ulcers, dry eye), hip dysplasia, pug dog encephalitis, skin fold infections, obesity, collapsed trachea
fields.health_screening: Ophthalmologist evaluation, hip evaluation, patellar evaluation. Regular eye and skin fold checks. Breathing assessment important.
fields.genetic_conditions: Pug Dog Encephalitis (PDE), Hemivertebrae, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA)
fields.grooming_details: Brush 2-3 times weekly. Clean facial wrinkles DAILY with damp cloth and dry thoroughly. Bathe monthly. Trim nails every 2-3 weeks. Check and clean eyes daily. Clean tail curl area.
fields.exercise_details: Short walks 20-30 minutes daily. Avoid exercise in heat/humidity. Indoor play sessions. Don't over-exercise due to breathing issues. Monitor for respiratory distress. Swimming requires life jacket.
fields.mental_stimulation: Puzzle toys, gentle training, indoor games, socialization. Food puzzles great for this food-motivated breed. Keep sessions short and fun.
fields.training_tips: Can be stubborn but food-motivated. Positive reinforcement essential. Short, fun sessions work best. Patient consistency needed. Housetraining can be challenging. Early socialization important.
fields.socialization_needs: Friendly by nature but early socialization beneficial. Generally good with people and pets. Exposure to various situations helps confidence. Love being around others.
fields.temperament_description: Charming, mischievous, loving, and playful. Even-tempered and stable. Very social - need lots of human companionship. Eager to please but can be stubborn. Sensitive and good-natured.
fields.behavior_traits: Shadow their owners, need constant companionship, food-obsessed, can be stubborn, snore loudly, make various sounds, playful but not hyperactive, attention seekers
fields.ideal_home: Apartment or house suitable. Must be climate-controlled (AC essential). Good for seniors, singles, families. Not for outdoor living. Need people who are home frequently - suffer from separation anxiety.
fields.climate_tolerance: Poor heat tolerance (dangerous in hot weather), moderate cold tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Serious breathing issues - heat can be fatal. Cannot tolerate heat, humidity, or strenuous exercise. Prone to serious eye injuries. High maintenance despite short coat. Snore, snort, wheeze constantly. May require expensive eye and breathing surgeries. Severe separation anxiety - not good alone.

fields.name: Siberian Husky
fields.overview: Siberian Huskies are energetic, beautiful, and athletic dogs bred for pulling sleds in harsh Arctic conditions. They are friendly, independent, and have striking blue or multi-colored eyes.
fields.breed_history: Bred by the Chukchi people of Siberia over 3,000 years ago as sled dogs. Brought to Alaska in 1909 for sled dog racing. Gained fame during the 1925 serum run to Nome, Alaska. Recognized by AKC in 1930.
fields.original_purpose: Sled pulling in Arctic conditions, transportation
fields.fun_fact_1: Huskies helped save the town of Nome, Alaska in 1925 by delivering life-saving serum through a blizzard (the famous 'Serum Run').
fields.fun_fact_2: They can have blue, brown, or one of each color eyes - both are acceptable in breed standards!
fields.fun_fact_3: Huskies don't bark - they howl, talk, and make various vocalizations.
fields.fun_fact_4: They can run 100+ miles per day and withstand temperatures as low as -60°F (-51°C).
fields.fun_fact_5: Huskies are master escape artists - they can jump fences, dig under them, or even open doors!
fields.fun_fact_6: Their thick coat has two layers that keep them warm in winter AND cool in summer.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed food, 3-4 cups daily divided into 2 meals. High protein (25-30%) for active dogs. Moderate fat. Working huskies may need higher calories. Avoid overfeeding inactive dogs.
fields.feeding_notes: Efficient metabolism - need less food than expected for size. Risk of bloat - avoid exercise after meals. Some have sensitive stomachs. Many are picky eaters. Fresh, cool water always essential.
fields.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, eye problems (cataracts, progressive retinal atrophy), hypothyroidism, zinc deficiency, autoimmune disorders
fields.health_screening: Hip evaluation, ophthalmologist evaluation yearly, thyroid testing. Genetic testing for PRA. Annual wellness exams.
fields.genetic_conditions: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Hereditary Cataracts, Corneal Dystrophy
fields.grooming_details: Brush 3-4 times weekly, daily during heavy shedding twice yearly. They 'blow' their coat completely. Bathe only when necessary (2-3 times yearly). Trim nails monthly. Check paws regularly.
fields.coat_type: Thick double coat with soft undercoat and straight guard hairs
fields.exercise_details: Needs 2+ hours of vigorous daily exercise. Running, hiking, biking, pulling activities ideal. Excellent for dog sports like sledding, skijoring. Must be on leash - very high prey drive. Needs large secure yard with 6ft+ fence.
fields.mental_stimulation: Needs lots of mental challenges. Puzzle toys, training, agility, nose work. Without adequate stimulation becomes destructive. Give them a 'job' to do.
fields.training_tips: Intelligent but independent and stubborn. Requires experienced, confident owner. Positive reinforcement but firm consistency. Poor recall - unreliable off-leash. Start training very early. High prey drive makes cat training difficult.
fields.socialization_needs: Early and extensive socialization essential. Generally friendly with people. Can be aggressive with small animals due to prey drive. Dog socialization important. Pack-oriented breed.
fields.temperament_description: Friendly, gentle, alert, and outgoing. Independent thinkers, not eager to please. Love people - terrible guard dogs. High energy and mischievous. Strong prey drive. Pack-oriented and social.
fields.behavior_traits: Escape artists, high prey drive, very vocal (howl/talk), destructive if bored, independent, love to run, dig extensively, friendly to everyone including strangers, not protective
fields.ideal_home: House with large securely fenced yard (6ft+ buried fence). Active owners who exercise extensively. Cold climates ideal. NOT for apartments or hot climates. Need experienced owners who understand working breeds.
fields.climate_tolerance: Excellent cold tolerance (prefer cold), poor heat tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Master escape artists - need very secure 6ft+ fencing. Extremely high exercise needs - will be destructive if under-exercised. High prey drive dangerous to cats and small pets. Cannot be trusted off-leash. Shed heavily year-round. Very vocal - may disturb neighbors. Not suitable for first-time owners or hot climates.

fields.name: Rottweiler
fields.overview: Rottweilers are confident, powerful, and loyal working dogs. They are excellent guardians with a calm confidence and natural protective instinct when properly trained.
fields.breed_history: Descended from Roman drover dogs. Used by butchers in Rottweil, Germany to herd livestock and pull carts to market. Nearly extinct in 1900s but revived as police and military dogs. Recognized by AKC in 1931.
fields.fun_fact_1: Rottweilers were one of the first guide dogs for the blind.
fields.fun_fact_2: They're nicknamed 'Rotties' and were once called 'Rottweil butcher dogs'.
fields.fun_fact_3: Rottweilers have one of the strongest bite forces of all dog breeds.
fields.fun_fact_4: They were nearly extinct in the 1900s but made a comeback through dedicated breeding.
fields.fun_fact_5: Rottweilers excel in police work, search and rescue, and as therapy dogs.
fields.fun_fact_6: Despite their tough appearance, they're known as 'Velcro dogs' for following owners everywhere.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed food, 4-6 cups daily divided into 2 meals. High protein (25-30%), glucosamine for joints. Puppy formula for large breeds to prevent rapid growth. Monitor portions to prevent obesity.
fields.feeding_notes: Risk of bloat - feed smaller meals, avoid exercise after eating. Prone to obesity - measure portions. Some have food sensitivities. May need joint supplements. Fresh water always available.
fields.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, osteosarcoma (bone cancer), bloat, heart disease, eye problems, cruciate ligament rupture, obesity
fields.health_screening: Hip and elbow evaluation, cardiac exam, ophthalmologist evaluation, knee evaluation. Regular cancer screening. Annual wellness exams essential.
fields.genetic_conditions: Hip Dysplasia, Elbow Dysplasia, Subvalvular Aortic Stenosis (SAS), Von Willebrand's Disease
fields.grooming_details: Brush weekly with firm bristle brush. Bathe every 8-12 weeks. Trim nails every 3-4 weeks. Clean ears weekly. Brush teeth regularly. Check and clean between paw pads.
fields.coat_type: Short, straight, coarse outer coat with undercoat
fields.exercise_details: Needs 60-90+ minutes daily exercise. Long walks, hiking, swimming, training activities. Needs both physical and mental exercise. Excellent for weight pull, obedience, tracking sports. Working breed needs a job.
fields.mental_stimulation: Advanced obedience, protection training, nose work, puzzle toys, agility. Highly intelligent - need mental challenges. Without stimulation can become destructive or aggressive.
fields.training_tips: Highly trainable but requires experienced, confident leader. Start early - critical socialization and obedience. Firm, fair, consistent training essential. Positive reinforcement with clear boundaries. Can be dominant - needs structure. Professional training recommended.
fields.socialization_needs: CRITICAL early and ongoing socialization. Naturally protective - must learn appropriate responses. Expose extensively to people, dogs, situations. Poor socialization can lead to aggression. Puppy classes and ongoing training essential.
fields.temperament_description: Confident, calm, courageous, and loyal. Affectionate with family but aloof with strangers. Natural guardian instinct. Self-assured and fearless. Devoted and loving to their people. Can be stubborn.
fields.behavior_traits: Strong guarding instinct, territorial, naturally protective, needs to be with family, can be dominant, loyal to death, observant and alert, may lean on people, strong-willed
fields.ideal_home: House with secure yard essential. Experienced owners who can provide firm leadership. Active families. Not for apartments. Not for first-time owners. Needs to be with family - not outdoor dogs.
fields.climate_tolerance: Good cold tolerance, moderate heat tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Requires experienced owner who can establish and maintain leadership. Strong protective instinct requires proper training and socialization. Breed-specific legislation in some areas. Significant liability - homeowner's insurance may exclude or charge more. Very powerful - can injure accidentally. Needs ongoing training throughout life. Not suitable for first-time owners.

fields.name: Shih Tzu
fields.overview: Shih Tzus are friendly, outgoing companion dogs bred as royal lap dogs in ancient China. They are affectionate, happy, and love being with people.
fields.breed_history: Bred in Tibetan monasteries, given as gifts to Chinese royalty. Name means 'Lion Dog' in Chinese. Favorites of Chinese emperors for centuries. Nearly extinct after Communist revolution but saved by breeding pairs brought to England and Europe. AKC recognition in 1969.
fields.fun_fact_1: Shih Tzus were bred to resemble lions, as depicted in traditional Chinese art.
fields.fun_fact_2: They were treasured by Chinese royalty and kept in the Forbidden City.
fields.fun_fact_3: The breed nearly went extinct during the Chinese Revolution.
fields.fun_fact_4: All modern Shih Tzus descend from just 14 dogs saved from extinction.
fields.fun_fact_5: Their long coat was meant to make them resemble the mythical lion of Buddha.
fields.fun_fact_6: Shih Tzus don't shed much, making them better for people with allergies.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality small breed food, 1/2 to 1 cup daily divided into 2-3 meals. Moderate protein and fat. May need dental-friendly kibble. Some require limited ingredient diets for allergies.
fields.feeding_notes: Prone to obesity - measure portions carefully. Small frequent meals better for tiny stomachs. May be picky eaters. Avoid table scraps. Fresh water always available, check water bowl as facial hair gets wet.
fields.common_health_issues: Eye problems (progressive retinal atrophy, corneal ulcers), brachycephalic syndrome, hip dysplasia, patellar luxation, ear infections, dental disease, allergies
fields.health_screening: Ophthalmologist evaluation, hip evaluation, patellar evaluation, cardiac screening. Regular dental checkups essential (every 6 months). Breathing assessment.
fields.genetic_conditions: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Hip Dysplasia, Renal Dysplasia
fields.grooming_details: Daily brushing REQUIRED to prevent mats. Professional grooming every 4-6 weeks. Many owners keep in 'puppy cut' for easier maintenance. Clean face daily, eyes daily, ears weekly. Trim hair between paw pads. Bathe every 3-4 weeks.
fields.coat_type: Long, flowing double coat (soft and silky)
fields.shedding_level: Low (minimal shedding but requires extensive grooming)
fields.exercise_details: Short walks 20-30 minutes daily. Indoor play adequate. Don't require extensive exercise. Avoid overexertion in heat. Good for apartments. More interested in lap time than running.
fields.mental_stimulation: Gentle training, puzzle toys, socialization, short play sessions. Not highly driven but enjoy interaction and learning tricks.
fields.training_tips: Can be stubborn. Positive reinforcement essential. Housetraining challenging - consistency and patience needed. Crate training helpful. Food motivation aids training. Keep sessions short and fun. Early socialization prevents shy or snappy behavior.
fields.socialization_needs: Early socialization important to prevent shyness or aggression. Generally friendly but can be wary of strangers. Good with other pets if socialized. Exposure to various situations beneficial.
fields.temperament_description: Affectionate, happy, outgoing, and trusting. Bred to be companions. Love everyone, especially their family. Friendly and less yappy than many toy breeds. Sturdy for their size. Sometimes stubborn but sweet-natured.
fields.behavior_traits: Loves to be center of attention, follows owners everywhere, can be stubborn, generally friendly to all, enjoys lap time, alert but not excessive barkers, good with other pets
fields.ideal_home: Apartment or house suitable. Good for seniors, singles, families with older children. Best as indoor dogs with their people. Need climate control. Good for less active owners.
fields.climate_tolerance: Poor heat tolerance due to flat face, moderate cold tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Very high maintenance grooming - daily brushing required, professional grooming expensive and ongoing. Prone to eye injuries due to prominent eyes. Brachycephalic breathing issues. Difficult to housetrain. Can be stubborn. Hair grows into eyes - must be tied up or trimmed. May have dental issues requiring extractions.

fields.name: Doberman Pinscher
fields.overview: Doberman Pinschers are loyal, fearless, and alert dogs with a sleek, athletic build. They are highly intelligent protectors with strong bonds to their families.
fields.breed_history: Developed in Germany around 1890 by Karl Friedrich Louis Dobermann, a tax collector who needed a protective companion. Mixed Rottweiler, German Pinscher, and other breeds. Quickly became valued as police and military dogs. Recognized by AKC in 1908.
fields.fun_fact_1: Dobermans were named after their creator, tax collector Louis Dobermann.
fields.fun_fact_2: They served as Marine Corps mascots in WWII and were called 'Devil Dogs'.
fields.fun_fact_3: Dobermans rank 5th in Stanley Coren's dog intelligence rankings.
fields.fun_fact_4: They have a reputation as fierce guards but are gentle 'velcro dogs' with family.
fields.fun_fact_5: A Doberman named Kurt became the first K-9 casualty of WWII and has a memorial in Guam.
fields.fun_fact_6: Dobermans can learn commands with fewer than 5 repetitions.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed food, 3-4 cups daily divided into 2 meals. High protein (25-30%), moderate fat. Glucosamine for joint health. Avoid bloat by not exercising after meals.
fields.feeding_notes: Risk of bloat - feed smaller meals, no exercise after eating, consider raised feeders. Some have food sensitivities. Maintain lean condition. Fresh water always available.
fields.common_health_issues: Dilated cardiomyopathy (heart disease), hip dysplasia, von Willebrand's disease, bloat, hypothyroidism, wobbler syndrome, progressive retinal atrophy
fields.health_screening: Cardiac evaluation (annually), hip evaluation, thyroid testing, von Willebrand's test, ophthalmologist evaluation. DNA test for DCM recommended.
fields.genetic_conditions: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM), von Willebrand's Disease, Hip Dysplasia
fields.grooming_details: Brush weekly with soft brush. Bathe every 8-12 weeks. Trim nails every 3-4 weeks. Clean ears weekly. Wipe with damp cloth as needed. Very low maintenance coat.
fields.exercise_details: Needs 60-90+ minutes vigorous daily exercise. Long runs, hiking, biking, swimming. Excel in agility, obedience, protection sports, tracking. Athletic dogs need both physical and mental exercise. Working breed needs jobs/tasks.
fields.mental_stimulation: Advanced obedience, protection work, nose work, agility, problem-solving activities. Extremely intelligent - need mental challenges daily or become destructive.
fields.training_tips: Highly trainable but requires experienced, confident handler. Start early with socialization and obedience. Positive reinforcement with firm consistency. Need structure and clear rules. Can be dominant - require strong leadership. Professional training often recommended.
fields.socialization_needs: CRITICAL extensive early socialization. Natural guarding instinct requires proper channeling. Expose to many people, dogs, situations. Without proper socialization can become fearful or aggressive. Ongoing socialization throughout life important.
fields.temperament_description: Loyal, fearless, alert, and highly intelligent. Devoted to family, aloof with strangers. Natural guardian. Confident and assertive. Energetic and athletic. Sensitive and responsive to training. Can be gentle despite tough appearance.
fields.behavior_traits: Strong protective instinct, territorial, bonds intensely with family, may be same-sex aggressive with dogs, alert watchdog, needs to be with people, can be dominant, loyal to the end, sensitive to owner's emotions
fields.ideal_home: House with secure yard essential. Active, experienced owners. Not for apartments or first-time owners. Needs to be with family - indoor dog. Best with adults or older children due to size and energy.
fields.climate_tolerance: Moderate cold tolerance, good heat tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Requires very experienced owner. Strong protective instinct needs proper training and management. Breed-specific legislation in many areas. Insurance may be difficult or expensive. Can be aggressive if improperly bred, trained, or socialized. High risk of heart disease - regular cardiac screening essential. Needs extensive daily exercise and mental stimulation. Not suitable for first-time owners.

fields.name: Chihuahua
fields.overview: Chihuahuas are the smallest dog breed but have huge personalities. They are sassy, loyal, and devoted to their owners with a bold, confident attitude.
fields.breed_history: Named after Chihuahua state in Mexico. Descended from Techichi, a companion dog of the ancient Toltec civilization. Discovered by Americans in the 1850s. Became popular in early 1900s. AKC recognized in 1904.
fields.original_purpose: Companion dog (possibly religious purposes in ancient times)
fields.fun_fact_1: Chihuahuas are the smallest dog breed in the world!
fields.fun_fact_2: They're born with a soft spot on their skull (molera) like human babies.
fields.fun_fact_3: There are two coat varieties: smooth coat and long coat.
fields.fun_fact_4: Ancient Aztecs believed Chihuahuas had mystical powers and could guide souls to the afterlife.
fields.fun_fact_5: They shiver/tremble frequently - not always from cold, but excitement or stress too!
fields.fun_fact_6: Chihuahuas have the longest lifespan of any dog breed, often living 15-20 years.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality toy/small breed food, 1/4 to 1/2 cup daily divided into 2-3 small meals. Higher calorie density for fast metabolism. Puppy formula important for young dogs to prevent hypoglycemia.
fields.feeding_notes: Prone to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) especially as puppies - small frequent meals essential. Obesity common - measure portions. Dental issues common - consider dental kibble. Fresh water always available.
fields.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, heart problems (mitral valve disease), hypoglycemia, dental disease, tracheal collapse, hydrocephalus, eye problems, shivering/trembling
fields.health_screening: Cardiac exam, patellar evaluation, ophthalmologist evaluation. Dental checkups every 6 months. Monitor for hypoglycemia in puppies.
fields.genetic_conditions: Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), Patellar Luxation, Hydrocephalus
fields.grooming_details: Smooth coat: brush weekly. Long coat: brush 2-3x weekly. Bathe monthly. Trim nails every 2-3 weeks. Clean ears weekly. Daily teeth brushing essential (prone to dental disease). Check eyes regularly.
fields.coat_type: Two varieties: smooth (short) coat or long coat
fields.exercise_details: Short walks 20-30 minutes daily. Indoor play often sufficient. Don't require extensive exercise. Avoid overexertion. Use harness (not collar) due to fragile trachea. Good for apartments.
fields.mental_stimulation: Training tricks, puzzle toys, socialization, gentle play. Intelligent and trainable. Enjoy learning and being challenged.
fields.training_tips: Intelligent but can be stubborn. Positive reinforcement essential. Start early to prevent 'small dog syndrome.' Housetraining challenging - patience and consistency. Crate training helpful. Early socialization critical to prevent fearfulness and aggression.
fields.socialization_needs: CRITICAL early and ongoing socialization. Prone to fearfulness and aggression without it. Expose to people, appropriate-sized dogs, sounds, situations. Can be snappy if not socialized. Puppy classes essential.
fields.temperament_description: Sassy, confident, loyal, and feisty. Bold personality in tiny body. Devoted to owners, often bonding with one person. Can be territorial and protective. Alert and suspicious of strangers. Sensitive and affectionate with family.
fields.behavior_traits: Trembles/shivers frequently, very vocal/yappy, bonds intensely with one person, can be possessive and jealous, alert watchdog, Napoleon complex, suspicious of strangers, may be snappy, doesn't know how small they are
fields.ideal_home: Apartment or house suitable. Best with adults or older children (too fragile for young kids). Good for seniors. Need supervision outdoors due to tiny size. Indoor living essential. Climate-controlled environment needed.
fields.climate_tolerance: Poor cold tolerance (needs sweaters), moderate heat tolerance
fields.special_considerations: Extremely fragile - inappropriate for homes with young children. Easily injured by falls, rough play, or being stepped on. Prone to 'small dog syndrome' if not trained properly. Very vocal - may bark excessively. Can be aggressive/snappy if not socialized. Cold sensitive - needs clothing in winter. Use harness instead of collar. Severe dental problems common requiring extractions. Prone to hypoglycemia.

fields.name: Dalmatian
fields.overview: Dalmatians are athletic, energetic dogs famous for their distinctive spotted coat. They are intelligent, outgoing, and require extensive exercise.
fields.breed_history: Ancient breed with uncertain origins, possibly dating back thousands of years. Named after Dalmatia region of Croatia. Used as carriage dogs, firehouse dogs, and circus performers. Popularized by Disney's '101 Dalmatians.' AKC recognized in 1888.
fields.original_purpose: Carriage dog (running alongside coaches), firehouse dog, guard dog
fields.fun_fact_1: Dalmatian puppies are born completely white - spots develop as they grow!
fields.fun_fact_2: They're the official firehouse dog breed and ran alongside fire carriages in the 1800s.
fields.fun_fact_3: Each Dalmatian has a unique spot pattern - like human fingerprints.
fields.fun_fact_4: They can run for miles without tiring - bred to run alongside carriages for 20+ miles daily.
fields.fun_fact_5: About 10-12% of Dalmatians are born deaf in one or both ears due to their genetics.
fields.fun_fact_6: Budweiser Clydesdales are always accompanied by a Dalmatian mascot!
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed food, 3-4 cups daily divided into 2 meals. Moderate to high protein (avoid organ meats high in purines). Low purine diet important. Ensure adequate hydration.
fields.feeding_notes: Unique metabolism - prone to urinary stones (urate crystals). Low purine diet essential. Avoid organ meats, sardines, anchovies, herring. Plenty of fresh water always. Some need prescription low-protein diet. Risk of bloat - avoid exercise after meals.
fields.common_health_issues: Deafness, urinary stones (urate), hip dysplasia, skin allergies, epilepsy, thyroid issues, eye problems
fields.health_screening: BAER testing for deafness, hip evaluation, thyroid testing, urinalysis, ophthalmologist evaluation. Regular urine checks for stones.
fields.genetic_conditions: Congenital Deafness (linked to white coat gene), Hyperuricosuria (urinary stones)
fields.grooming_details: Brush 2-3 times weekly (daily during heavy shedding). Bathe every 6-8 weeks. Trim nails every 3-4 weeks. Clean ears weekly. Check between paw pads regularly.
fields.exercise_details: Needs 90-120+ minutes vigorous daily exercise. Running, hiking, biking, swimming. Excellent jogging partners. High endurance - bred to run for hours. Excel in agility, flyball, dock diving. Not suitable for sedentary owners.
fields.mental_stimulation: Agility, obedience, nose work, puzzle toys, long hikes with varied terrain. Intelligent and need mental challenges. Can become destructive without adequate stimulation.
fields.training_tips: Intelligent but can be stubborn and independent. Positive reinforcement essential. Sensitive - harsh methods backfire. Start training early. Consistency key. May be challenging for first-time trainers. Socialization critical. Can be strong-willed.
fields.socialization_needs: Early and extensive socialization essential. Can be reserved/aloof with strangers. May be aggressive toward unfamiliar dogs without proper socialization. Expose to many people, dogs, situations starting early.
fields.temperament_description: Energetic, playful, intelligent, and independent. Outgoing with family, reserved with strangers. Athletic and dignified. Can be stubborn. Loyal and protective. Sensitive and remember negative experiences. Need to be part of family activities.
fields.behavior_traits: High energy always, can be destructive if bored, may be stubborn, reserved with strangers, needs to be with family, athletic and agile, some can be hyperactive, sensitive to owner's moods
fields.ideal_home: House with large secure yard essential. Very active owners who run/exercise extensively. Not for apartments. Not for first-time owners. Best with older children due to energy level. Need to be included in family activities.
fields.climate_tolerance: Good tolerance to both heat and cold
fields.special_considerations: Extremely high exercise requirements - will be destructive without it. Shed constantly and heavily - 'dalmation hair is a condiment in your house.' 10-12% born deaf - requires special training considerations. Unique dietary needs due to urate stone risk. Can be stubborn and difficult to train. May be too energetic for young children. Not suitable for first-time owners or sedentary lifestyles.

fields.name: Boxer
fields.overview: Boxers are fun-loving, energetic, and loyal dogs with a strong, muscular build. They are playful clowns with their families and excellent watchdogs.
fields.breed_history: Developed in Germany in the late 1800s from the now-extinct Bullenbeisser and English Bulldog. Used for bull-baiting, hunting, and later as military/police dogs. Became popular in America after WWI. AKC recognized in 1904.
fields.original_purpose: Bull-baiting, hunting large game, guard dog
fields.fun_fact_1: Boxers got their name from their tendency to stand on hind legs and 'box' with their front paws!
fields.fun_fact_2: They hold the record for longest tongue on a dog - 17 inches!
fields.fun_fact_3: Boxers are one of the few breeds that use their front paws extensively - almost like hands.
fields.fun_fact_4: They're known as 'Peter Pan' dogs because they don't mature until 3 years old and stay puppy-like.
fields.fun_fact_5: Boxers served as message carriers, pack dogs, and guard dogs in both World Wars.
fields.fun_fact_6: They're natural clowns and are famous for making funny faces and sounds!
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality large breed food, 3-4 cups daily divided into 2 meals. Moderate to high protein (25-28%), moderate fat. Some need grain-free due to sensitivities. Monitor for food allergies.
fields.feeding_notes: Risk of bloat - feed smaller meals, no exercise after eating. Many have food sensitivities or allergies. May need limited ingredient diet. Some are sensitive to wheat, corn, soy. Excessive drooling - keep water bowl clean. Fresh water always.
fields.common_health_issues: Cancer (very high rate), hip dysplasia, heart problems (cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis), bloat, hypothyroidism, allergies, boxer colitis
fields.health_screening: Cardiac evaluation (annually), hip evaluation, thyroid testing, ARVC DNA test. Cancer screening important. Regular wellness exams essential.
fields.genetic_conditions: Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC/Boxer Cardiomyopathy), Degenerative Myelopathy, Hip Dysplasia
fields.grooming_details: Brush weekly with rubber curry brush. Bathe every 6-8 weeks. Wipe face daily (droolers). Trim nails every 3-4 weeks. Clean ears weekly. Check between paw pads regularly.
fields.exercise_details: Needs 60-90+ minutes vigorous daily exercise. Running, hiking, playing, training activities. Excel in agility, obedience, flyball. High energy puppies need controlled exercise. Don't over-exercise in extreme heat (brachycephalic). Swimming with supervision.
fields.mental_stimulation: Training, puzzle toys, nose work, agility, interactive play. Intelligent and need mental challenges. Clicker training excellent. Get bored easily - need variety.
fields.training_tips: Intelligent but can be stubborn. Positive reinforcement essential - they shut down with harsh methods. Short, fun sessions best. Very food motivated. Slow to mature - patience needed. Consistency key. May be challenging but responds well to firm, fair training. Early socialization critical.
fields.socialization_needs: Early and ongoing socialization important. Generally friendly but can be territorial or dog-aggressive without proper socialization. Exposure to people, dogs, situations essential. Puppy classes highly recommended.
fields.temperament_description: Fun-loving, playful, energetic, and loyal. Patient and protective with family, especially children. Can be wary of strangers. Confident and fearless. Clownish and silly. Very affectionate 'velcro dogs.' Stay puppy-like for years. High-spirited and exuberant.
fields.behavior_traits: Jump and wiggle when excited, use paws like hands, make funny faces and sounds, drool, may be stubborn, lean on people, 'kidney bean' wiggle dance, may jump on people, energetic and bouncy
fields.ideal_home: House with yard preferred. Active families with children ideal. Need people who are home frequently. Not for apartments unless extensively exercised. Good with active owners. Need to be part of family - indoor dogs.
fields.climate_tolerance: Good cold tolerance, moderate heat tolerance (brachycephalic - monitor in heat)
fields.special_considerations: Very high cancer rate (38% of deaths). Heart problems common - annual cardiac screening essential. Excessive energy when young - may knock over small children accidentally. Slow to mature - extended puppyhood (3 years). Drool and pass gas. Can be dog-aggressive, especially same-sex. May have food allergies requiring special diet. Not suitable for owners wanting calm, mature dog.

fields.name: Border Collie
fields.overview: Border Collies are extremely intelligent, energetic working dogs bred for herding. They are the smartest dog breed and require extensive mental and physical stimulation.
fields.breed_history: Developed in the border region between England and Scotland for herding sheep in rough terrain. Name comes from this border origin. 'Collie' possibly from Scottish dialect for sheepdog. Became famous for herding prowess. AKC recognized in 1995.
fields.fun_fact_1: Border Collies rank #1 in Stanley Coren's dog intelligence rankings - the smartest breed!
fields.fun_fact_2: They have an intense stare called 'the eye' used to control sheep.
fields.fun_fact_3: A Border Collie named Chaser knew over 1,000 words - more than any other animal!
fields.fun_fact_4: They can learn a new command in less than 5 repetitions and obey 95% of the time.
fields.fun_fact_5: Border Collies dominate competitive dog sports like agility, flyball, and disc competitions.
fields.fun_fact_6: They can work all day in extreme conditions, covering 50+ miles daily while herding.
fields.diet_recommendations: High-quality medium/large breed food, 2-3 cups daily divided into 2 meals. High protein (25-30%) for working dogs. Moderate fat. Active dogs may need more calories. Adjust based on activity level.
fields.feeding_notes: High metabolism due to extreme activity. Monitor weight and adjust portions based on exercise. Working dogs need higher calories. Fresh water always essential, especially during activities.
fields.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, epilepsy, eye problems (progressive retinal atrophy, collie eye anomaly), deafness, MDR1 drug sensitivity
fields.health_screening: Hip evaluation, ophthalmologist evaluation, MDR1 genetic test (drug sensitivity), DNA tests for CEA and PRA. Annual wellness exams.
fields.genetic_conditions: Collie Eye Anomaly (CEA), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), MDR1 mutation (drug sensitivity), Epilepsy
fields.grooming_details: Brush 2-3 times weekly, daily during shedding seasons. Two coat types: rough and smooth. Bathe every 6-8 weeks. Trim nails every 3-4 weeks. Check and clean ears weekly. Check paws regularly.
fields.coat_type: Two varieties: rough (medium-length) or smooth (short), both double-coated
fields.exercise_details: Needs 2+ hours of intense exercise daily PLUS mental work. Running, hiking, herding, agility, flyball, disc sports. Exercise alone insufficient - need jobs/tasks. Excel at dog sports. Not satisfied with just walks - need purpose-driven activity.
fields.mental_stimulation: CRITICAL - need constant mental challenges. Advanced training, herding, agility, nose work, puzzle toys, problem-solving. Will create their own 'jobs' (often destructive) if not given tasks. Need variety and challenges daily.
fields.training_tips: Extremely trainable but need experienced handler. Learn incredibly fast. Positive reinforcement. Need advanced training and constant challenges. Can outsmart novice trainers. May develop neurotic behaviors without proper outlets. Herding instinct needs channeling. Thrive on having a 'job.'
fields.socialization_needs: Early socialization important. Generally good with people. May herd children, pets, or vehicles without training. Exposure to various situations helps. Can be shy or nervous without socialization. Ongoing training throughout life essential.
fields.temperament_description: Extremely intelligent, energetic, alert, and responsive. Intense and driven. Highly focused when working. Affectionate with family. Can be reserved with strangers. Sensitive to owner's cues. Always analyzing and thinking. Need purpose and work to be happy.
fields.behavior_traits: Intense stare ('the eye'), may herd children/pets/cars, workaholic mentality, can be obsessive (balls, shadows), sensitive, watch owner constantly, need purpose, destructive if bored, may be neurotic without outlet, very focused
fields.ideal_home: Active, experienced owners who can provide extensive exercise and mental stimulation. Farm or large property ideal. Dog sports enthusiasts perfect. NOT for typical pet homes or first-time owners. Need experienced handlers who understand working breeds.
fields.climate_tolerance: Good tolerance to both cold and heat (built for outdoor work)
fields.special_considerations: NOT suitable for typical pet homes. Extreme exercise and mental stimulation requirements - 2+ hours daily minimum. Will become destructive, neurotic, and develop behavioral problems without adequate outlets. May herd children nipping at heels. Can develop obsessive behaviors (shadow chasing, spinning). Too intelligent and driven for most owners. Require experienced handler committed to extensive daily training and activity. Not for first-time owners or sedentary lifestyles.
